questions.question_text: Which of the following devices can utilize VLANs to secure networks?

discussion.content:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtual_LAN
A virtual LAN (VLAN) is any broadcast domain that is partitioned and isolated in a computer network at the data link layer (OSI layer 2).
And switch ports connect a VLAN.

questions.question_text: After upgrading a smartphone's OS, Joe, a user, reports the smartphone no longer connects to his automobile automatically when near it. Joe restarts the smartphone, but the problem persists. Which of the following should a technician do NEXT to restore the previous functionality?

discussion.content: Why would the Bluetooth turn off after an upgrade? And since the upgrade causes the problem, I would revert back, no? lol

comments.content: It can happen, I've seen it.

Revert back would take way longer than just reenabling the bluetooth. It can be anything, it is up to you as a technician to figure what the problem is and in the shortest amount of time so the client can go back to working or doing personal stuff. Nobody likes to wait on tech.

discussion.content: I would say that bluetooth is turned off.
This question doesn't give nearly enough information for this to be the answer.

comments.content: The question states that the phone doesn't connect automatically when he enters the car. The question then goes on to ask, "Which of the following should a technician do NEXT to restore the previous functionality?". If the previous functionality was that it connected to the car radio automatically, then it can't be a USB plug, as this is a manual connection. If airplane mode was never enabled in the first place, then enabling it, just to disable it again won't do anything. The question is also asking what you should do NEXT, your next step should not be to rollback the phone's OS before checking if BT is enabled. Therefore, B is the correct answer.

choices.D: Enable airplane mode and then disable airplane mode
choices.C: Perform a rollback of the smartphone's OS
choices.A: Connect the smartphone to the automobile via USB

discussion.content: This is D. because he is able to view mail (not receiving new) and the next thing you should check is to make sure it is not in airplane mode. That will block connecting out. SSL/TLS has nothing to do with not being able to send anything, the account password could also be correct but if that was not change I would look at airplane mode first.

comments.content: Because, If you've spent any amount of time here, you'd know by now that 30% to almost half of the answers that examtopics gives as correct are actually wrong. If yo went by the answers they give here without checking the discussions, you'd for sure fail and lose all your money! (I believe they are in kahoots with CompTIA to get you to lose your money and keep paying for retakes.... otherwise they would have corrected many of the wrong answers that have been identified over a year ago in this here database of questions)

Which is why I am amused at the people who are trying to LEARN the material fighting tooth and nail with the professionals presenting the material. Who are the experts and who are the students? I am not trying to be rude, but refusing to accept and understand the lessons is antithetical to why we are here in the first place and likely to be an impedance to the process of learning.

discussion.content: These comments are useless as most of you have no clue what you're talking about.

IMAP is used for receiving email, while SMTP is used for sending email. Since Joe is able to view emails but cannot send them, the issue likely lies with the SMTP configuration. Many email servers require SSL/TLS encryption for outgoing mail as a security measure. If this setting is not enabled, the SMTP server may reject the connection attempt, resulting in an error message.
Answer should be C. I deal with this issue at work all the time and it's due to an incorrect username/password for at least one of the server configs.
the NEXT thing to do as a tech is check the internet connectivity. D the other options just don't seem as simple and straight-forward as checking airplane mode.

comments.content:
Yeah, me too...
But the point if the user is offline and can read the mail because of POP3, then D will be a possible answer. Since it says SMTP is valid...I will assume it is because of the internet connection

discussion.content: Ok so I was first thinking maybe B for secure sending of email but secure email can also involve S/mime. But for the connection/tunnel SSL/TLS. Checking to ensure SSL/TLS is being used won't resolve it though. Not B then. Not C: if he has a connection and is able to view mail then he must have the right password to login and view the email. Not D because it was he would not be able to connect and use IMAP or SMTP because they require a internet connection and if airplane mode is on then the radios would be switched off and a connection could not be made. A is the only option left and POP3 takes the email off the server and stores it on your device and the email can also be read offline with POP3. I find it hard to know if he is online or not but I guess he is offline because SMTP won't send a email offline. I don't like this question.

what I don't understand is, an IMAP is already set up and "Joe" is able to view email but receives an error while trying to send a message but he sees a valid SMTP server and port.

Problem solved, IMAP is for receiving mails and SMTP for sending. So, when he has got both activated, what then needs to be done and why is the answer A. As per my understanding, If he is having trouble sending the message, SMTP is what needs to be looked at and not POP3. 

Can someone clarify and explain please.
Thought Airplane mode is the correct ans but when I tested with my phone no error appeared when its on. I will go for TLS choice.
Put pop3 only because that term is used when talking about email and I donâ€™t know anything else about this subject kinda like how comptia does not know anything

from https://www.reddit.com/r/CompTIA/comments/hvgboc/confused_about_practice_question_regarding_email/ -- u/GenericDisturbance
Ok, so, it's not D, because under IMAP the messages stay on the server (unlike POP3 (unless you reconfigure it a bit)), so you must have the internet to be able to view the messages. It's not C, because you can view the messages. Easy so far.

With the others, I'm trying to follow their logic.

What I think they mean is:

With B, you'd need and see a different port number than 25 on the SMTP side if it was SSL/TLS, and the question just says it's "valid", i.e. doesn't need changing.

Option A then. Setting to POP3, if the IMAP isn't working properly in conjunction with the SMTP server, should then allow the "valid" SMTP server to function, which is especially true of some old email providers and old smartphones that would just download the mail preview content in a quick send/receive to then be used offline (saves mobile data?).

The badly worded question, or very old question. I think we're supposed to see some sort of significance in the "smartphone" maybe?

comments.content: You failed to understand IMAP/POP3. With IMAP email DO stay on server AFTER you readed/downloaded. That's mean that you can wipe your phone, change device or whatever and the email will be there for you to download in every scenario. IMAP doesn't mean email stay ONLY on the server, but ALSO in the server. POP3 work the opposite, once you download/open the mail in any device that mail will be deleted from the server (after a while) so if you change device or wipe the phone that mail will be lost for good.

I believe the answer is D. Remember that IMAP caches local copies of the email onto all of your devices, therefore you can still view the email without the internet. On the other hand, SMTP requires an internet connection to send emails.

discussion.content: As someone that worked at a domain provider, we also sold email application licenses such as Outlook. We had many customers call about email issues during my time there and our solution never was to switch the customer to a POP3 email. Not only is this an incoming server and won't effect your ability to send outgoing mail, but it doesn't even make sense to configure on a mobile device.
I am confused how it can be POP3. could anyone explain?
Has anyone actually seen this question on a the test and got it right or wrong?

comments.content: Your wrong about that, you cannot view emails without internet in IMAP, you need internet for that. Only POP3 emails can be viewed without internet.

you're just wrong. I just tested it right now, i set airplane mode, no mobile data, no wifi. I open my gmail and bam, i'm reading my mail :). Also i can even open and read the emails i never opened, that's is actually weird
binayD is right. As an example, if you are using iPhone 'Mail' application and gmail is set up there (which is IMAP by default) you are able to see the cached messages without internet access.

discussion.content: Its D. When you are in air plane mode you can read all your downloaded emails i.e. emails downloaded in your account but you wont able to send messages. A message will be displayed as phone is offline etc.

An incorrect password sounds simple, but many turn out to be this simple issue.
If you can receive email and cannot send email this means the authentication required by the outgoing server is not configured or needs to be re-configured.Now you should know the correct answer.

B. Ensure the SSL/TLS option is being used
When I check my iPhone via settings=>Passwords and Accounts=>gMail=>Account=>SMTP=>SMTP Server, I see an option to turn SSL on or off and port 465 is selected, and that the Username and Password fields say "optional." So it seems that SSL turned off would be the culprit.
Not D - Airplane mode turns off your internet connection - so you cannot receive or send email. Not A - Pop3 is for receiving email. 
Not C - Username and password are optional fields

B - "Joe sees a valid SMTP server and port" -- it says the server and port are valid - but it doesn't say that the SSL/TLS box is ticked for the SMTP configuration. NOTE: POP3 is for incoming mail only, so will not help with sending mail.
Answer is B
I'm guessing POP is the answer because it's another choice to use for receiving mail and IMAP is not working so I guess it's saying switching receiving protocols is the answer

pop3 and imap are only for receiving emails, the only difference is that imap can be used on differents devices at the same time without delete the emails, pop3 will delete emails from the server, pop3 is not intended to be used in different device at the same time with the same account

it was said valid SMTP server and port, means encryption may be correct.
So the only reason it can be POP3, there was a type which need to verify your account that [pop before send mail].

comments.content: Did you get any wrong in section 2.1?

discussion.content:
Hi,

I had exactly this question some hours before.
I selected Answer: B

If this question is from domain 1.6 this answer will be right, as I have no failures in.
Any comments on if you would also thinks its doamin 1.6 or any other thoughts?
The user is having trouble authenticating when sending. It is likely TLS/port related.

comments.content: But nervermind, using POP3 will not fix the Problem with sending mails, as POP3 is not responsible and able to do this.

discussion.content: This questions is poorly worded. "Joe sees a valid SMTP server and port" suggests he is trying to use SMTP to send e-mail but maybe we are reading too much into this. If he really is using SMTP, choice B might be true in this situation. If he is not using SMTP, then he could use POP3 as choice A suggests.

comments.content: Incorrect...Both Imap and pop3 are only used to receive emails...SMTP is used when sending emails.
I thought that was SMTP.

"POP3 supports sending", it is wrong. SMTP is for sending. 
And no one now configures POP3 on a mobile phones usually.

This is absolutely wrong!!!

In computing, the Post Office Protocol (POP) is an application-layer Internet standard protocol used by e-mail clients to retrieve e-mail from a mail server.

POP is not for sending!

discussion.content: IMAP is only for receiving emails and does not support sending emails. For that, you need POP3 which does support sending.
I suppose it might be B!
confused as well

comments.content: POP3 is retrieval, IMAP is storage.
More accurately, IMAP is for receiving mail AND storing it on an email server.

POP3 and IMAP only retrieve emails. The difference between the two being that POP3 retrieves and removes the email from the server (which is why it isn't as common with it handling multi device syncing so poorly. You are thinking of MAPI which is the only protocol to both send an retrieve. Otherwise SMTP needs to be configured in conjunction with POP3 or IMAP to send emails.

discussion.content: Why would he need a POP3 connection, when he's already using IMAP? How is that related to the issue whatsoever?

questions.question_text: Joe, a user, sets up an IMAP connection on his smartphone to connect to webmail. Joe is able to view email, but he receives an error message when trying to send a message. When viewing the mail client's configuration, Joe sees a valid SMTP server and port. Which of the following should Joe check NEXT to resolve the issue?

choices.B: Ensure the SSL/TLS option is being used
choices.A: Configure the email account as a POP3 connection
choices.D: Make sure the smartphone is not in airplane mode
choices.C: Check that the account password is still valid
There is a corrupt file on the hard drive
choices.A: The disk has already been finalized
choices.D: The files are not compatible with the type of disk used

questions.question_text: A user is connected to a docking station with an optical drive and is trying to back up personal files to removable media, but is encountering write errors. Which of the following is MOST likely cause of the errors?

comments.content: Rookie.....comprehension is KEY to understanding these questions.
It says encountering write errors. It would be happened when the disk is not writable.

discussion.content: This question does not give enough information
The creators of these questions should put a correct explanation, so that the one who is studying may understand why this question and not another.
I think you guys know too much to the point where you overthink every question. Think like you just finished study the CompTIA A+ Core 1.

comments.content: You gonna copy and paste this on every question? lol

The answer is A - the question specifies optical media which is the key here. OK it just mentions a write error, but it only mentions trying to write files to the disk - there would be no read error if he user hasn't tried to read files.

A: disk is already finalized - Once you've finished writing to a CD/R of DVD/R you "Finalize" the disk meaning NO further information can be written to the disk. ANY future attempts to write would result in errors. (The question doesn't specify if it is or is not a rewriteable disk but think this is the implication here as we're looking for the most likely cause.

B: Files are encrypted - Doesn't matter, you're writing the data not trying to understand it.

C: Corrupted file on hard drive - Possibly this would cause an error, however the question asks for the most likely and if he's "backing up" files it's likely files that are known to be good (NOT a guarantee just my interpretation)

D: Files not compatible with type of disk - Doesn't make sense an optical disk is a data disk, as long as there is enough space for the file to fit we should be able to write the file (AFAIK, correct me if i'm wrong)

Looking at it all i think we're meant to whittle it down to A or C to begin with, but out of the 2 I find A far more likely

discussion.content: It would make the most sense that the answer is "D: The files are not compatible with the type of disk used", because it doesn't say that it's a read/write error. It just says a write error.

Me not knowing exactly what the answer is, I eliminated "A", and possibly "B."
To me if the files are corrupt it would cause a read/write error. Also if the files are not compatible with the type of disk used, then the files wouldn't be able to be written on the disk. Remember there are CDs and DVDs.

questions.question_text:
A customer wants to purchase a new home computer. The machine will mainly be used for Internet browsing and streaming video, except on weekends when the customer's son will use it to play games with friends.
Which of the following should the technician focus on to meet these requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: The answer is correct. You need 16GB of RAM at a min to play games these days ( with 32 - GB being the best ). Forget the DDR 2 that is just the type of ram that existed back then. The 16 GB is what is more important. And of course, a quad-core is a min. Dual Monitors is not correct , lets be honest the best config is a ultra-wide single monitor. SSD is not required , but it helps. 80 mm fans help but its not required unless you have heat problems.
Look at the question, it asks about a home computer not a whole setup. Think of what actually comes with the computer, the answers are! B & D are our answers
On one of the sims, dual monitors is one of the correct answers for a gaming PC...
